g.text: In the present work, the hydration characteristics of four kinds of Ca-montmorillonite with
erent layer charge densities were studied by means of MD simulations and experiments. The
research results indicate that the layer charge density of montmorillonite has a signiﬁcant e
hydration properties. If the charge density of montmorillonite is low (0.375), the water molecules are
mainly concentrated on the sides of the central axis about –1.3 Å and 1.5 Å, and the self-di
cient of water molecules is only 1.67
s. As the layer charge density increases (0.500,
0.563 to 0.688), the water molecules in the montmorillonite interlayer extends to –2.5 Åand 2.4 Åaway
fromthe central axis, and the self-di
cient of water molecules decreases to 0.87
s, respectively. The concentration of water molecules in the
central axis is reduced, the arrangement of water molecules is more compact, and the structure is
obvious. With the increase of charge density, Ca
appears to gradually shift fromthe vicinity of the
central axis to the Si-O surface on both sides in the montmorillonite layer, and the Ca
more tightly packed together than that of H
. The reason is that with the increase of charge density
of montmorillonite, the number of hydrogen bonds formed between the H
more and more water molecules are bound to the Si-O surface, and under the action of electrostatic
are pulled towards the Si-Osurface; this results in the higher the layer
charge density of montmorillonite, the worse the hydration performance. The experimental results ﬁt
Data curation, S.J.; formal analysis, D.L. and G.Y.; funding acquisition, J.Q. and G.W.;
methodology, G.L. and X.L.; project administration, J.Q. and X.L.; resources, J.Q. and G.W.; software, G.L. and
D.L.; supervision, X.Z.; visualization, P.C.; writing—original draft, J.Q. and G.L.
This work was supported by a grant fromNational Natural Science Foundation of China—“Design of
structure and gelling performance of Montmorillonite
Alkylammonium based on the adsorption properties of
Alkylammoniumon Montmorillonite(No:51774200)”, and “Study on the immobilization e
heavy metal in sulﬁde-mine tailings by chelating agent modiﬁed bentonite” (No:51764003).
This work was funded by National Natural Science Foundation of China (No: 51774200,
No:51764003). Andthe authors are thankful to the editors andthe anonymous reviewers for the valuable comments
The authors declare no conﬂict of interest.
1. Bergaya, F.; Theng, B.K.G.; Lagaly, G. Modiﬁed Clays and Clays Minerals. In
Bergaya, F., Theng, B.K.G., Eds.; Elsevier: Amsterdam, Netherlands, 2008; Volume 145, pp. 261–263.
2. Pierre, M.; Piero, U.; Mariona, S.; Hernandez, E.R. Ab initio molecular dynamics study of the hydration of
) in a montmorillonite model. Inﬂuence of isomorphic substitution.
3. Zhang, X.; Yi, H.; Zhao, Y.; Song, S. Quantitative Determination of Isomorphous Substitutions on Clay
Mineral Surfaces through AFMImaging: A Case of Mica.
Colloids Surf. A Physicochem. Eng. Asp.
4. Salles, F.; Douillard, J.M.; Bildstein, O.; Ghazi, S.E.; Damme, H.V. Di
usion of Interlayer Cations in Swelling
Clays as a Function of Water Content: Case of Montmorillonites Saturated with Alkali Cations.
, J. Montmorillonite modiﬁed with unconventional surfactants fromthe
series of octylammonium-based cations: Structural characterization and hydration properties.
6. Tangaraj, V.; Janot, J.M.; Jaber, M.; Bechelany, M.; Balme, S. Adsorption and photophysical properties of
ﬂuorescent dyes over montmorillonite andsaponite modiﬁedby surfactant.
7. Weng, Z.; Wang, J.; Senthil, T.; Wu, L. Mechanical and thermal properties of ABS
nanocomposites for fused deposition modeling 3D printing.
